details.title: Relating integrated circuit yield and time-dependent reliability for various defect density distributions

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Eng., Konkuk Univ., Seoul, South Korea

p: Kyungmee O. Kim is an assistant professor of Industrial Engineering at Konkuk University in Seoul, Korea. She obtained her Ph.D. degree in the Department of Industrial Engineering from Texas A&M in 1999. Her research interests include statistical quality control, burn-in, yield and reliability optimization, fault diagnosis, and condition based maintenance.

authors.name: K.O. Kim

details.abstract: The issue of developing a model to estimate field reliability from process yield has received a growing interest in recent years. Thus far, only Poisson and negative binomial relationships have been obtained, assuming that the number of yield defects is independent of the number of reliability defects in a device. In this paper, we derived explicit yield-reliability relationships for various defect density, such as Erlang, uniform, and triangle distributions, using a multinomial distribution to consider a correlation between the number of yield defects, and the number of reliability defects. The proposed model has advantages over previous models for any defect density distribution to determine the optimal burn-in time.

references.title: Statistical Theory of Reliability and Life Testing

context.text: In reliability theory [1], reliability is defined as the probability of a device operating continuously without failures for a predetermined operation time \$t\geq 0\$.

references.text: R. E. Barlow, F. Proschan, Statistical Theory of Reliability and Life Testing, 1975, Holt Rinehart & Winston.

references.title:
Extending intergrated-circuit yield models
to estimate early life reliability

context.text: However, reliability interests are often limited to extrinsic failures because the current advanced technologies in the product design and process development eliminate wear-out failures over many products' lifetimes [2], [7], [19].
Reference [2] investigated the negative binomial relationship derived from a gamma defect density that considers the defect clustering over the wafer.

All references [2], [7], [13], [18], [19] defined reliability as the probability of a device having no reliability (or latent) defects, where the time-independent reliability defect density is assumed to be a fraction of yield defect density.
All previous references [2], [7], [9], [11], [13], [18], [19] assumed that the number of yield defects is independent of the number of reliability defects in a device.
One might think that reliability is defined by incorporating the yield information [2].
This is equivalent with the relation model presented in [2], [7], [18], [19] if a single field operation time is considered.

The corresponding negative binomial relationship between yield and reliability is derived by
 Notice that (7) is equivalent to the relation model presented in [2] if a single mission time is considered.

links.abstract: The integrated yield-reliability model for integrated circuits allows one to estimate the yield, following both wafer probe and burn-in testing. The model is based on the long observed clustering of defects and the experimentally verified relation between defects causing wafer probe failures, and defects causing infant mortality failures. The 2-parameter negative binomial distribution is used to describe the distribution of defects over a semiconductor wafer. The clustering parameter /spl alpha/...

references.text: T. S. Barnett, A. D. Singh, V. P. Nelson, "Extending intergrated-circuit yield models to estimate early life reliability", IEEE Transactions on Reliability, vol. 52, no. 3, pp. 296-300, 2003.

links.abstract: The development and refinement of net-die-per-wafer yield models during the past 25 years are reviewed, and the models are tested for accuracy by comparison with actual yield data from seven separate chip companies. Depending on chip size, the more accurate models are the Poisson and the negative binomial. Several models for line yields in wafer fabrication are also covered. For predicting yields of larger-die-area very large-scale integration, the negative binomial model is the more accurate, b...

references.text: J. A. Cunningham, "The use and evaluation of yield models in integrated circuit manufacturing", IEEE Transactions on Semiconductor Manufacturing, vol. 3, pp. 60-71, 1990.

references.title: Introduction to Semiconductor Device Yield Modeling

context.text: Similar to the traditional yield modeling that uses different distributions for \$N_{y}\$ [6], we consider different distributions for \$N\$ to derive explicit yield and reliability relationships.

The most popular model used to predict IC yield can be derived from the Poisson pmf, assuming that the probability of obtaining a defect is the same on one chip as on another:
 where
 and
 Although the Poisson yield model is widely used, it sometimes gives a lower predicted yield than what is observed as it ignores the defect clustering [6].

The negative binomial yield is obtained by
 The clustering factor \$\alpha\$ determines the degree of clustering, and if \$\alpha=1\$, then the negative binomial yield is called the Seed's yield model [6].
For any other defect density distributions, such as an exponential or a half Gaussian distribution [6], similar yield-reliability relationships can be derived.

That is, an acceptable form for \$f(D)\$ is selected to compute the yield, and if the yield model gives yield values that match the actual yield data reasonably well, then the choice of \$f(D)\$ is supported [6].

references.text: A. V. Ferris-Prabhu, Introduction to Semiconductor Device Yield Modeling, 1992, Artech House.

references.title:
Reliability defect detection and screening during processing:
theory and implementation

context.text: However, reliability interests are often limited to extrinsic failures because the current advanced technologies in the product design and process development eliminate wear-out failures over many products' lifetimes [2], [7], [19].
It is known that manufacturing defects, created on IC devices during manufacturing processes, determine both yield and extrinsic failures [7].
References [7], [13], [18], [19] studied the Poisson relationship between yield and reliability assuming a constant defect density.

All references [2], [7], [13], [18], [19] defined reliability as the probability of a device having no reliability (or latent) defects, where the time-independent reliability defect density is assumed to be a fraction of yield defect density.
All previous references [2], [7], [9], [11], [13], [18], [19] assumed that the number of yield defects is independent of the number of reliability defects in a device.

Thus, the probability of a defect being a yield defect is calculated by
 Although \$s(x)\$ varies depending on the process lines, process time, learning experience gained, and other variables; it generally peaks at a critical size, and then decreases on either side of the peak [5], [7], [8], [12], [17].

Although \$a, b\$, and \$x_{c}\$ are process dependent constants, it is known that \$a=3\$ and \$b=1\$ agree well with experimental data, and \$x_{c}\$ must be smaller than the minimum width or spacing of the defect monitor [7].
This is equivalent with the relation model presented in [2], [7], [18], [19] if a single field operation time is considered.

links.abstract: The authors derive a model that relates electrical in-process measurements to reliability defect occurrence. The model begins with an understanding of reliability defect physics and statistics and then uses elements of semiconductor manufacture yield modeling. An experiment, using intensive microscopic inspections, that was used to verify this model is described. The type and nature of yield and reliability defect monitors and the use of in-process electrical measurements of these monitors for r...

references.text: H. H. Huston, C. P. Clarke, "Reliability defect detection and screening during processing: theory and implementation", Proceedings of 30th International Reliability Physics Symposium, pp. 268-275, 1992.

references.title: Modeling manufacturing yield and reliability

context.text: Because this definition of reliability is not consistent with reliability estimated from the time-to-first-failure data, [9], [11] developed relationships between yield and time-dependent reliability, applicable only to gate oxide failures.
All previous references [2], [7], [9], [11], [13], [18], [19] assumed that the number of yield defects is independent of the number of reliability defects in a device.
Then the lifetime of a chip is determined by the time required for a defect size to reach a certain threshold at which a chip fails [9], [11].

links.abstract: In this paper, we introduce the concept of reliability defect, present the time-dependent defect growth model during operations based on a defect-related gate oxide breakdown mechanism, and build the yield-reliability relation model. Discussions presented here can also be applicable to other device failures when different physics-of-failure mechanisms are found. Through the relation model, it is possible to find a minimum level of latent defect screening to assure the required level of reliabili...

references.text: T. Kim, W. Kuo, "Modeling manufacturing yield and reliability", IEEE Transactions on Semiconductor Manufacturing, vol. 12, pp. 485-492, 1999.

references.title: Optimal burn-in decision making

context.text: Reference [10] studied an optimal burn-in time to minimize a cost function considering yield and reliability.

context.text: Because this definition of reliability is not consistent with reliability estimated from the time-to-first-failure data, [9], [11] developed relationships between yield and time-dependent reliability, applicable only to gate oxide failures.
All previous references [2], [7], [9], [11], [13], [18], [19] assumed that the number of yield defects is independent of the number of reliability defects in a device.
Then the lifetime of a chip is determined by the time required for a defect size to reach a certain threshold at which a chip fails [9], [11].

Then the probability of a defect being a reliability defect for an operation time \$t\$ is given by [11]
 In general, the defect size at time \$t\$ may be estimated by the original defect size and operation time.
Reference [11] provided a model for the optimal burn-in based on the yield-reliability relationship.

links.abstract: This paper presents an overview of yield, reliability, burn-in, cost factors, and fault coverage as practiced in the semiconductor manufacturing industry. Reliability and yield modeling can be used as a foundation for developing effective stress burn-in, which in turn can warranty high-quality semiconductor products. Yield models are described and their advantages and disadvantages are discussed. Both yield reliability relationships and relation models between yield and reliability are thoroughl...

references.text: W. Kuo, T. Kim, "An overview of manufacturing yield and reliability modeling of semiconductor products", Proceedings of IEEE, vol. 87, pp. 1329-1344, 1999.

references.title:
Relation between yield and
reliability of integrated circuits: experimental results and application to
continuous early failure rate reduction programs

context.text: References [7], [13], [18], [19] studied the Poisson relationship between yield and reliability assuming a constant defect density.

All references [2], [7], [13], [18], [19] defined reliability as the probability of a device having no reliability (or latent) defects, where the time-independent reliability defect density is assumed to be a fraction of yield defect density.
All previous references [2], [7], [9], [11], [13], [18], [19] assumed that the number of yield defects is independent of the number of reliability defects in a device.

links.abstract: The relation between yield and early failures as encountered in the field was investigated with several high volume IC's manufactured in several processes. A clear correlation between yield and reliability was found that obeys a simple model. The model also provides the ability to predict the FIT or PPM level of a given IC based on its yield. Using these results we illustrate how a wafer fab may improve the reliability level of its products in a controlled way.

references.text: F. Kuper, J. Vander Pol, E. Ooms, T. Johnson, R. Wijburg, "Relation between yield and reliability of integrated circuits: experimental results and application to continuous early failure rate reduction programs", Proceedings of 34th International Reliability Physics Symposium, pp. 17-21, 1996.

context.text:
For example, a gate-oxide time-to-failure, and an original defect size \$X_{0}=x_{0}\$, are related by [14]
 where \$t_{x0}\$ is the time to oxide breakdown, \$\tau\$ is a constant (1 × \$10^{-11}\sec), G\$ is a constant (350 MV/cm), \$V\$ is the operation voltage across the oxide, \$w\$ is the oxide thickness, \$x_{0}\$ is the defect size that represents the severity of the defect, and \$w-x\$ is the effective oxide thickness.

links.abstract: A technique of predicting the lifetime of an oxide to different voltages, different oxide areas, and different temperatures is presented. Using the defect density model in which defects are modeled as effective oxide thinning, many reliability parameters such as yield, failure rate, and screen time/screen yield can be predicted. This modeling procedure is applicable to both wafer-level and long-term reliability tests. Process improvements including defect gettering and alternative dielectrics su...

references.text: J. C. Lee, I. C. Chen, C. Hu, "Modeling and characterizing of gate oxide reliability", IEEE Transactions on Electronic Devices, vol. 35, pp. 2268-2277, 1988.

references.title:
New defect size distribution
function for estimation of chip critical area in integrated circuit yield
models

context.text: A gamma distribution is another used defect size distribution [15], [16].

links.abstract: The Gamma function is proposed to approximate the measured lithographic defect size distribution for the estimation of the chip critical area. It is shown that, compared to the commonly used 1/x/sup 3/ function for approximation of the lithographic defect size distribution, the Gamma function provides much better agreement with the measured data, thus leading to a more accurate estimation of the chip critical area.

references.text: Z. Stamenkovic, N. Stojadinovic, "New defect size distribution function for estimation of chip critical area in integrated circuit yield models", Electronics Letter, vol. 28, pp. 528-530, 1992.

links.abstract: A physics-of-failure approach to reliability prediction for integrated circuits is discussed. The analysis described is based upon the expectation that no integrated circuit can ever be free of imperfections and the assumption that both microscopic (point) defects and macroscopic flaws play influential roles in determining IC reliability. It is demonstrated that the microscopic defects can be directly implicated in gradual degradation over time via analyses related to those used in modeling a va...

references.text: J. Stevenson, J. A. Nachlas, "Micorelectronic reliability prediction derived from component defect densitities", Proceedings of Annual Reliability and Maintainability Symposium, pp. 366-370, 1990.

links.abstract: Clear relations have been established between E-sort yield and bum-in, EFR and field failure rates for nearly 50 million high volume products in bipolar, CMOS and BICMOS technologies from different waferfabs. The correlations obey a simple model that assumes that the reliability defect density is a fraction of the waferfab defect density and that rootcauses of failures are the same. The model allows a die size independent prediction and assessment of FIT and PPM reliability levels of an IC just ...

references.text: J. Van der Pol, F. Kuper, E. Ooms, "Relation between yield and reliability of integrated circuits and application to failure rate assessment and reduction in the one digit fit and ppm reliability era", Microelectronics Reliability, vol. 36, pp. 1603-1610, 1996.

context.text: However, reliability interests are often limited to extrinsic failures because the current advanced technologies in the product design and process development eliminate wear-out failures over many products' lifetimes [2], [7], [19].
References [7], [13], [18], [19] studied the Poisson relationship between yield and reliability assuming a constant defect density.

All references [2], [7], [13], [18], [19] defined reliability as the probability of a device having no reliability (or latent) defects, where the time-independent reliability defect density is assumed to be a fraction of yield defect density.
All previous references [2], [7], [9], [11], [13], [18], [19] assumed that the number of yield defects is independent of the number of reliability defects in a device.

Reference [19] began with a time-independent Poisson relation model with
 where \$\gamma\$ is the ratio of reliability defect density to yield defect density.

links.abstract: This paper addresses the question of under what conditions burn-in can be eliminated. Based on data of more than 30 million sold devices, the effect of screening of latent defects at electrical test on product reliability has been investigated. The results are combined with the yield-reliability relation and an experimentally determined failure rate time evolution, yielding a model that allows determination of the sense or nonsense of burn-in or screens at electrical test quantitatively. The mod...

references.text: J. Van der Pol, E. Ooms, T. Hof, F. Kuper, "Impact of screening of latent defects at electrical test on yield-reliability relation and application to burn-in elimiation", Proceedings of 36th International Reliability Physics Symposium, pp. 370-377, 1998.
